awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Probing Crystal Nucleation in Soft Confinement with Molecular Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Controlling crystal nucleation in liquids is important in applications related to pharmaceutical processing and designing materials.  Crystal growth can be controlled to desired size, shape, and structure by fine tuning of the local environment in which nucleation takes place at the molecular level.  The goal of this project is to understand crystal nucleation in liquids confined by soft hydrogel matrices. The confinement geometry and chemistry within the matrices may alter nucleation pathways and resulting crystallization. Advanced molecular simulation techniques will be used to discover the mechanisms by which soft hydrogel matrices influence crystal nucleation. The educational part of this project includes the development of a new short course and outreach activities to K-12 students in the Houston area.

The overarching hypothesis will be tested by deploying rare-event molecular simulation techniques to address three specific aims: (1) to elucidate the mechanisms by which soft hydrogel matrices influence ice nucleation thermodynamics; (2) to identify the effects of soft confinement on the crystallization kinetics of water in hydrogels; (3) to probe the pathways for calcium carbonate precipitation in polymer brushes with tunable architectures. Free energy methods will be used to compute nucleation barriers and identify metastable intermediates, while path sampling algorithms will be employed to characterize crystallization kinetics and mechanisms. This combination of techniques will reveal the effects of matrix properties (density, surface chemistry, and morphology) on nucleation and thereby transform understanding of the physical processes controlling crystallization in soft matrices.  A course focusing on reproducibility in science will be developed, The Art of Reproducible Science, and will be taught to graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Houston and broadly disseminated through online video tutorials. Outreach activities will be developed to provide K-12 students with opportunities to learn about research and STEM career paths through participation in the annual Lemelson-MIT JV InvenTeams program, GRADE summer program for women and underrepresented minorities, Texas Soft Matter Meeting, and Southwest Catalysis Society Meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The focus of this NSF CAREER grant was to investigate the crystallization of liquid and how this process is altered when liquids are in contact or confined within soft materials such as polymer hydrogels and surface-grafted brushes. Controlling crystal nucleation in liquids using soft matrices has the potential to transform applications ranging from materials design to pharmaceutical processing: attaining crystals of the desired size, shape, and form requires finely tuning the local environment in which nucleation takes place at the molecular level. Experiments show that confining liquids in soft polymer matrices dramatically changes their crystallization behavior. Modulating matrix density, polymer chemistry, and morphology can produce different crystal forms and significantly alter crystallization rates. The factors controlling crystal nucleation in soft matrices remain vigorously debated and poorly understood, in part because existing experimental methods cannot resolve the nanoscopic length and time scales required to characterize the very early stages of crystallization. Thus, we used advanced computer simulation techniques to study crystallization in bulk liquids and to develop models of soft matrices for studying crystallization in confined environments.

 First, we performed computer simulation studies to investigate the behavior of water as it is cooled below its normal freezing point. At sufficiently low temperatures, we observed that models of water spontaneously separate into two distinct liquid phases: a high-density liquid phase and a low-density liquid phase. The dynamics of molecules in the low-density liquid phase were found to be sluggish and spatially heterogeneous compared to those in the high-density liquid phase.  These unusual dynamics in the low-density liquid phase were associated with regions of enhanced local structural order that fostered the formation of small crystalline ice nuclei. After a stabilization time, these nuclei developed into larger nuclei that continue to grow. The type of crystalline ice that formed was shown to be determined by the structure of the small nuclei, which favored the formation of cubic ice crystals over normal (hexagonally structured) ice under these conditions.  These findings are consistent with the nonclassical (multistep) crystallization mechanisms that have been observed in experiments and computer simulations of a variety of different systems.  

Second, we developed molecular models for soft matrices including polymer solutions, hydrogel networks, and charged polymer brushes. We showed that surface-grafted polymer brushes with acid and basic monomers can be modeled using advanced computer simulation techniques for modeling acid-base reactions. These simualtions demonstrated that the structure of the brushes is strongly affected by environmental conditions such as pH and salt concentration. Thus, these systems provide an interesting testbed for study the effects of soft confinement on crystal nucleation, whereby the structure of the soft matrix may be tuned by altering environmental conditions to ultimately control crystallization outcomes.

Broader Impacts:

This proposal supported the training of 4 PhD students and 1 undergraduate student.  The students received training in molecular modeling techniques (molecular dynamics, reaction ensemble Monte Carlo, and multi-particle collision dynamics), statistical mechanics and thermodynamics, programming in Python and C++,  and high-performance computing environments.  The PI and the supported students participated in outreach efforts hosted by the University of Houston (UH) at the Houston Energy Festival (2018, 2019, 2023, 2024) and hosted by the Society of Rheology at the Houston Children’s Museum (2018), and were involved in helping to organize a virtual Texas Soft Matter meeting (2021); opportunities for in-person participation were limited for three years because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Lastly, the PI developed a short course, “The Art of Reproducible Science,” which covers strategies for carefully documenting and “debugging” research protocols, and address current best practices as well as emerging technological and ethical issues related to data management and sharing. The PI integrated the course into the UH’s NSF-sponsored REU program, “Materials for Sustainable Energy and Manufacturing” (NSF Award #1659763). The PI also continues to present contents from this course each semester to graduate and undergraduate researchers at UH through the Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Department’s “Lunch and Learn” program.
